metadata.case_name: Appellant Company v. M. A. Khader and M. A. Jabbar

facts.text: Appellant is a limited Company carrying on transport business in South Arcot District.
M. A. Khader holds 13 shares and M. A. Jabbar holds 163 shares in the Company.
Articles 29 and 30 of the Articles of Association provide for notice requiring payment of call money, interest and expenses, and forfeiture if not complied with.
On January 2, 1957, the board of directors passed a resolution calling the unpaid amount of Rs. 25/- on each share.
On January 3, 1957, a call notice was issued to shareholders requesting payment on or before January 19, 1957. The call notices were duly served on the contesting respondents.

On January 20, 1957, Company issued notice under Art. 29 to respondents calling upon them to pay Rs. 25/- per share, interest at six per cent and expenses by January 30, 1957 at registered office, failing which shares liable to forfeiture.
Respondents did not pay the call monies despite notice dated January 20, 1957.
On February 11, 1957, board of directors passed resolution under Art. 30 forfeiting the shares held by respondents.

On November 8, 1957, respondents filed two separate applications under s. 155 of the Indian Companies Act, 1956 in Madras High Court praying that forfeitures be set aside and share register rectified.

Ramachandra Ayyar, J. allowed the applications, ordered rectification of registers. Decision affirmed by appellate court (Madras High Court in O.S. Appeals Nos. 55 and 56 of 1959, judgment dated December 21, 1961). Courts held notice dated January 20, 1957 defective due to absence of particulars of interest and expenses.
Company appeals to Supreme Court by certificate granted by High Court.

On January 18, 1957, M. A. Jabbar, M. A. Khader and others filed Application No. 119 of 1957 in Madras High Court under ss. 402 and 237, obtained interim stay of collection pursuant to notice dated January 3, 1957. Stay communicated January 21, 1957.
On January 30, 1957, Court passed modified interim order restraining forfeiture, directed M. A. Jabbar to pay call money into Court within one week.
Call money not paid into Court. On February 8, 1957, Court vacated stay order.
Application No. 119 of 1957 dismissed on April 10, 1957.

legal_issues.text: Whether the notice dated January 20, 1957 under Art. 29 was defective for lack of particulars of expenses, rendering the forfeiture invalid.
Whether the courts below had jurisdiction under s. 155(1)(a)(ii) of Companies Act, 1956 to rectify the share register due to invalid forfeiture.
Whether respondents waived right to challenge forfeiture due to proceedings in Application No. 119 of 1957.
Whether relief under s. 155 should be denied in discretion due to respondents' conduct as trade rivals acting mala fide.

petitioner_arguments.text: Notice dated January 20, 1957 was valid; point of invalidity not pleaded, only raised in argument.
By reason of proceedings in Application No. 119, respondents waived and abandoned right to challenge forfeiture.
Order dated January 30, 1957 substituted fresh notice under Art. 29; non-compliance validates forfeiture.
Relief under s. 155 discretionary; refuse due to respondents' mala fide conduct as trade rivals; they come with unclean hands.
Issue under s. 155(1)(a)(ii) is whether name omitted without sufficient cause, not whether shareholder has sufficient cause.

respondent_arguments.text: Steps prescribed before forfeiture not complied with; notice dated January 20, 1957 defective due to absence of particulars of interest and expenses.

court_reasoning.text: Notice under Art. 29 must disclose sufficient information on amount of expenses for shareholder to know precise payment required to avoid forfeiture. Amount of expenses not disclosed, so defective. Proper notice is condition precedent to forfeiture.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Slight defect in notice invalidates it and is fatal to forfeiture.

court_reasoning.text: No opinion on interest demand due to incomplete record of call regulations, but agree defective re expenses.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Object of notice is to give opportunity for payment.

court_reasoning.text: Forfeiture invalid, so name omitted from register without sufficient cause; jurisdiction under s.155(1)(a)(ii) attracted.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Issue is whether omission without sufficient cause.

court_reasoning.text: No waiver or abandonment inferred from Application No. 119 proceedings. Order Jan 30 not a notice under Art. 29.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Only notice under Art. 29 is dated Jan 20, which is defective.

court_reasoning.text: Relief under s.155 not to be arbitrarily refused where matter summarily decidable. Respondents assert legal right, not equitable relief; their other conduct unrelated to invalidity.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Unclean hands maxim inapplicable; no relation to subject-matter.

holdings.text: Notice dated January 20, 1957 defective for lack of particulars of expenses; forfeiture invalid.
Court has jurisdiction under s.155(1)(a)(ii) to rectify register where omission due to invalid forfeiture.
No waiver by respondents; court order not substitute notice.
Relief under s.155 granted; respondents' conduct not bar.

precedents_cited.relevance: Standard articles provide for interest on unpaid calls; analogous to company articles.

statutes_cited.relevance: Rectification of share register if name omitted without sufficient cause; applications for relief.

statutes_cited.relevance: Standard provision for interest on unpaid calls.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the appeals, affirmed lower courts' orders setting aside forfeiture and directing rectification of share register, holding the notice under Art. 29 defective due to lack of particulars of expenses.
outcome.relief_granted: Forfeitures set aside; rectification of share register.

key_quotes.text: The notice under Art. 29 must disclose to the shareholder... sufficient information from which he may know with certainty the amount which he should pay in order to avoid the forfeiture.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: A proper notice under Art. 29 is a condition precedent to forfeiture, under Art. 30. Here, the notice under Art. 29 is defective, and the condition precedent is not complied with.
key_quotes.speaker: court

key_quotes.text: In the result, the appeals are dismissed.
key_quotes.speaker: court
